scenarioDescription:
The HD 215497 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 215497 is a star with 0.67 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.85 times its radius. It is located 132.25 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 215497 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 215497 system


HD 215497 b

HD 215497 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2010-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 215497 b is 6.360 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 215497 b is 2.400 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 215497 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 215497 c

HD 215497 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2010-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.28 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 215497 c is 104.940 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 215497 c is 12.500 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 215497 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HD 215497, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: HD 215497 - System With 2 Exoplanets
